svcproc.title: MACHINING ROTORS
svcproc.para: The terms micrometers and micro-inch describe surface finish or smoothness and are different from runout and parallelism. These terms refer to the flatness of the rotor surface.

step1.para: The rotors are considered acceptable for continued service use without machining when:

step2.para: Lateral runout and thickness variation is within specification.
Rotor braking surfaces are smooth with even wear. Light grooving or heat checking is acceptable.
Brake pads are being replaced with the SAME brake pad material type.
Rotor thickness is more than the minimum allowable thickness.

step1.para: The rotors can be machined to provided a new, smooth braking surface. The rotors should be machined when:

step2.para: Lateral runout or thickness variation exceed the maximum specification.
Rotor braking surfaces are worn unevenly, have deep grooves, are scored, heat spotted, heat checked or has excessive brake pad material transfer.
Replacing brake pads with a DIFFERENT brake pad material type.

step1.para:
If the rotor will not true up before the minimum allowable thickness, the rotor must be replaced. Refer to SPECIFICATIONS
.

specpara.para:
IMPORTANT - Rotors are identified by the minimum allowable thickness that can be used. Refer to Figure 10.
Any rotor thinner than the minimum dimension must not be used.

svcproc.para: Be sure to use good sharp cutting tools and proper cutting feed and speed when machining the rotor. Avoid dull cutting tools and "tool chatter". After machining, the rotor braking surfaces must be clean and smooth with a surface finish of 40 to 120 micro-inch (1.016 to 3.048 micrometers).
